gen:ReportedAttribute.com:Text: Goal 2. End hunger, achieve food security, improve nutrition and promote sustainable agriculture

2.2 By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving by 2025 internationally agreed targets for stunting and wasting in children under 5 years, and meet the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant or breastfeeding women and the elderly
2.2.2. Chronic malnutrition rate
ISTEEBU
NDAYISENGA Modest
Department of Social Studies and Statistics and Poverty Monitoring, Ponit focal ODD
Head of Service and Focal Point
ndayimode2010@gmail.com
Stunting, or chronic malnutrition, is a form of undernutrition. Stunting is the result of prolonged and repeated episodes of undernutrition.
Nutritional surveys
Data are collected from household surveys using the "household" questionnaire
The probable date of the next collection will be 2020
ISTEEBU
ISTEEBU is responsible for compiling this indicator at the national level
ISTEEBU is the body recognized by the Burundian government for the collection, processing and dissemination of official statistics helping in planning and decision-making.
The indicator is relevant because it reports on the nutritional situation of children under 5 years old.
Updating the indicator requires a household survey which requires a lot of resources and most of which is donated by partners
It is defined as a height-for-age (TAZ) z-score less than two standard deviations of the median of the reference population.
The results of the survey are validated at two levels: technical validation and official validation before publication
The indicator is available at national level, province, Place of residence (Total; Girls; Boys; 0-11 months; 12-23 months; 24-59 months)
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
Report of the Survey on the nutritional situation in Burundi

Goal 2. End hunger, achieve food security, improve nutrition and promote sustainable agriculture

2.2 By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving by 2025 internationally agreed targets for stunting and wasting in children under 5 years, and meet the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant or breastfeeding women and the elderly
2.2.1. Number of underweight children under 5 (Acute malnutrition)
ISTEEBU
NDAYISENGA Modest
Department of Social Studies and Statistics and Poverty Monitoring, Ponit focal ODD
Head of Service and Focal Point
ndayimode2010@gmail.com

Acute malnutrition is a form of undernutrition. It is caused by a decrease in food intake and / or associated disease causing bilateral edema and / or sudden weight loss. Its severe form is characterized by the presence of bilateral edema or emaciation (low weight-for-height z-score or low MUAC). We distinguish the Global Acute Malnutrition (MAG) which is the sum of Moderate Acute Malnutrition (MAM) and Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM).
Nutritional surveys
Data are collected from household surveys using the "household" questionnaire
The probable date of the next collection will be 2020
ISTEEBU
ISTEEBU is responsible for compiling this indicator at the national level
ISTEEBU is the body recognized by the Burundian government for the collection, processing and dissemination of official statistics helping in planning and decision-making.
The indicator is relevant because it reports on the nutritional situation of children under 5 years old.
Updating the indicator requires a household survey which requires a lot of resources and most of which is donated by partners
It is defined as a weight-for-height (PTZ) z-score less than two standard deviations of the median of the reference population.
The results of the survey are validated at two levels: technical validation and official validation before publication
The indicator is available at national level, province, Place of residence (Total; Girls; Boys; 6-11 months; 12-23 months; 24-59 months)
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
Report of the Survey on the nutritional situation in Burundi
Goal 2. End hunger, achieve food security, improve nutrition and promote sustainable agriculture

Acute malnutrition is a form of undernutrition. It is caused by a decrease in food intake and / or associated disease causing bilateral edema and / or sudden weight loss. Its severe form is characterized by the presence of bilateral edema or emaciation (low weight-for-height z-score or low MUAC). We distinguish the Global Acute Malnutrition (MAG) which is the sum of Moderate Acute Malnutrition (MAM) and Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM).
Nutritional surveys
Data are collected from household surveys using the "household" questionnaire
The probable date of the next collection will be 2020

The indicator is relevant because it reports on the nutritional situation of children under 5 years old.
Updating the indicator requires a household survey which requires a lot of resources and most of which is donated by partners

The results of the survey are validated at two levels: technical validation and official validation before publication
The indicator is available at national level, province, Place of residence (Total; Girls; Boys; 6-11 months; 12-23 months; 24-59 months)
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
Report of the Survey on the nutritional situation in Burundi
Goal 2. End hunger, achieve food security, improve nutrition and promote sustainable agriculture

2.2 By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving by 2025 internationally agreed targets for stunting and wasting in children under 5 years, and meet the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant or breastfeeding women and the elderly
2.2.3. Prevalence of underweight in children under 5 years old
ISTEEBU
NDAYISENGA Modest
Department of Social Studies and Statistics and Poverty Monitoring, Ponit focal ODD
Head of Service and Focal Point
ndayimode2010@gmail.com
It is a composite indicator and results in low weight for age. Weight-for-age (PAZ) is a nutritional index that reflects a combination of acute and chronic growth disorders.
Nutritional surveys
Data are collected from household surveys using the "household" questionnaire
The probable date of the next collection will be 2020
ISTEEBU
ISTEEBU is responsible for compiling this indicator at the national level
ISTEEBU is the body recognized by the Burundian government for the collection, processing and dissemination of official statistics helping in planning and decision-making.
The indicator is relevant because it reports on the nutritional situation of children under 5 years old.
Updating the indicator requires a household survey which requires a lot of resources and most of which is donated by partners
It is calculated by a weight for age of the child compared to a standard or to a reference population of the same age.
The results of the survey are validated at two levels: technical validation and official validation before publication
The indicator is available at national level, province, Place of residence (Total; Girls; Boys; 0-11 months; 12-23 months; 24-59 months)
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
Report of the Survey on the nutritional situation in Burundi

Goal 2. End hunger, achieve food security, improve nutrition and promote sustainable agriculture

2.3 By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous people, family farmers, pastoralists and fishermen, including by ensuring equal access to land, other productive resources and factors of production, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and non-agricultural employment
2.3.1. Quantity of annual production (in tonnes)
MINEAGRIE
MBAZUMUTIMANA Dieudonne
dembaze@yahoo.fr
it is the ratio between the volume of agricultural production on the number of agricultural workers or the volume of agricultural labor hours
Ton per worker
National Agricultural Survey
Data are collected from household surveys using the "household" questionnaire
The probable date of the next collection will be 2021 (Next DHS)
MINEAGRIE
MINEAGRIE is responsible for compiling this indicator at the national level

The Ministerial departments in charge of statistical production are members of the SSN and have a mandate to collect, process and disseminate official statistics helping in planning and decision-making.
The indicator is relevant because it reflects the situation on plant and animal production
Updating the indicator requires a household survey which requires a lot of resources and most of which is donated by partners
Ratio of the volume of agricultural production to the number of agricultural workers or the volume of agricultural labor hours, expressed in tonnes per worker
The results of the survey are validated at two levels: technical validation and official validation before publication
The indicator is available at national level
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
Report of the National Survey of Agriculture in Burundi

The results of the survey are validated at two levels: technical validation and official validation before publication
The indicator is available at national level
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
Report of the National Survey of Agriculture in Burundi
Goal 2. End hunger, achieve food security, improve nutrition and promote sustainable agriculture
2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure that everyone, especially the poor and those in vulnerable situations, including infants, have year-round access to healthy, nutritious and sufficient food
2.1.1 Prevalence of undernourishment
ISTEEBU
NDAYISENGA Modest
Department of Social Studies and Statistics and Poverty Monitoring, Ponit focal ODD
Head of Service and Focal Point
ndayimode2010@gmail.com

Household size 1) has minimal food consumption, but unable to meet certain essential non-food expenses without depleting livelihoods, 2) with poor food consumption, or, Marginal capacity to meet minimum food needs only through accelerated exhaustion of livelihoods, 3) with significant deficiency in food consumption, or, Extreme loss of livelihood resulting in severe deficiencies in food consumption, or worse as a proportion of the total number of households
Food Security Investigations
Data are collected from household surveys using the "household" questionnaire
The probable date of the next collection will be 2020
ISTEEBU
ISTEEBU is responsible for compiling this indicator at the national level
ISTEEBU is the body recognized by the Burundian government for the collection, processing and dissemination of official statistics helping in planning and decision-making.
The indicator is relevant because it reflects the nutritional situation and food security of the population.
Updating the indicator requires a household survey which requires a lot of resources and most of which is donated by partners

Ratio of households 1) has minimal food consumption, but unable to meet certain essential non-food expenses without depleting livelihoods, 2) with poor food consumption, or, Marginal capacity to meet minimum food needs only through accelerated exhaustion of livelihoods, 3) with significant deficiency in food consumption, or, Extreme loss of livelihood resulting in severe deficiencies in food consumption, or worse and the total number of households, multiplied by 100
The results of the survey are validated at two levels: technical validation and official validation before publication
Available at the national level and by place of residence (National; Urban; Rural)
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
FAO report

Goal 2. End hunger, achieve food security, improve nutrition and promote sustainable agriculture

2.3 By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous people, family farmers, pastoralists and fishermen, including by ensuring equal access to land, other productive resources and factors of production, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and non-agricultural employment
2.3.2. Number of functional umbrella organizations in the tea, cotton, palm, rice, milk, etc. sectors.
Not available
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level

Goal 2. End hunger, achieve food security, improve nutrition and promote sustainable agriculture

2.c Adopt measures aimed at ensuring the proper functioning of markets for foodstuffs and derived products and at facilitating rapid access to information relating to these markets, including the level of food reserves, in order to help limit the extreme food price volatility
2.c.1 Indicator of tariff anomalies for foodstuffs
Not available
Goal 2. End hunger, achieve food security, improve nutrition and promote sustainable agriculture

2.c.1 Indicator of tariff anomalies for foodstuffs

2.c.1 Indicator of tariff anomalies for foodstuffs

Goal 2. End hunger, achieve food security, improve nutrition and promote sustainable agriculture

2.a Increase, in particular through strengthening international cooperation, investment in rural infrastructure, agricultural research and extension services and the development of technologies and plant and animal gene banks d '' livestock, in order to strengthen the agricultural productive capacities of developing countries, in particular the least developed countries
2.a.1 Agricultural orientation index of public expenditure
Not available
Goal 2. End hunger, achieve food security, improve nutrition and promote sustainable agriculture

2.a.1 Agricultural orientation index of public expenditure
Not available

2.a.1 Agricultural orientation index of public expenditure

Goal 2. End hunger, achieve food security, improve nutrition and promote sustainable agriculture

2.a Increase, in particular through strengthening international cooperation, investment in rural infrastructure, agricultural research and extension services and the development of technologies and plant and animal gene banks d '' livestock, in order to strengthen the agricultural productive capacities of developing countries, in particular the least developed countries
2.a.2 Total public contributions (official development assistance plus other public contributions) allocated to the agricultural sector
This is the total amount of official development assistance allocated to the agriculture sector
Sum of public aid
Not available
Goal 2. End hunger, achieve food security, improve nutrition and promote sustainable agriculture

2.b Correct and prevent restrictions and distortions hampering the functioning of world agricultural markets, including through the parallel elimination of all forms of agricultural export subsidies and all export measures having equivalent effect, in accordance with mandate of the Doha Development Round
2.b.1 Export subsidies in the agricultural sector
This is the total amount of export subsidies granted in the agriculture sector
Sum of export subsidies granted in the agriculture sector
Not available
